Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI CI Engineer: Adapting Research Workflows to Use Campus Cyberinfrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research workflows across many domains from life sciences to social and behavioral sciences, are scaling to require more computational analysis of much larger data sets. Workflows that have leveraged local computation and data storage resources must be transformed to use larger shared compute facilities like the UC Berkeley Savio supercomputing cluster, and national centers like NERSC and XSEDE. However, researchers have struggled to connect their data sources (such as laboratory instruments, remote data-sets, etc.) to the shared computation and storage resources in an efficient, productive workflow. Barriers range from poor network throughput, to inexperience with data management and shared computing infrastructure and best practices.

The Berkeley Research Computing (BRC) program is adding cyber-infrastructure engineering support to engage research groups to understand their needs, and to design and implement effective workflows that take advantage of campus and national computation and data management resources. These research engagements transform existing workflows to advance project-specific research goals, but also provide concrete templates that other research groups can leverage, and an architectural pattern for research engagement going forward.

The BRC CI Engineer leverages campus resources including a Science DMZ that connects high-speed state and national network links, including California's Advanced Research and Education Network (CENIC) and the Energy Sciences Network (ESNet), to campus infrastructure, including the BRC Savio supercomputing cluster. The BRC CI Engineer draws upon campus expertise in networking, high-performance computing, and research data management, as well as the domain expertise of campus partners. As research engagements are completed and documented, we will expand faculty understanding of the new scalable workflows, and enable them to address the next generation of research questions.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though UC Berkeley is internationally known for its research enterprise, for the most part researchers were developing and managing their own computing infrastructure. UC Berkeley had launched a research computing program in order to develop services that were sustainable and could be shared by researchers across campus. This was certainly needed for researchers working in disciplines that were accustomed to services like High Performance Computing clusters. However it was increasingly evident that researchers in other disciplines, including the Biological Sciences and Behavioral and Social Sciences, needed cyberinfrastructure that surpassed what their laptops and workstations were capable of. Through this NSF award, UC Berkeley sought to improve access to powerful shared cyberinfrastructure for a wider range of researchers. 


The project was successful and has been an integral part of the growth of Research IT and the Berkeley Research Computing program. In particular, the CI Engineer has been a critical component in the development of a research facilitation and consulting team that has helped thousands of campus researchers. The UC Berkeley approach to research facilitation comprises a multi-tiered team of undergraduate and graduate students, part-time staff from other units, and staff in the Research IT support unit, including the Cyberinfrastructure Engineer. With these partners in the Research IT Consulting team, the CI Engineer helped develop a successful high-touch consulting service that has gained trust across the UC Berkeley research community. More recently, the CIE has participated in the merger of the consulting operations of Berkeley Research Computing consulting team with those of the Research Data Management program (a partnership between Research IT and the University Library). This new Research IT Consulting team is developing into a researcher-friendly consulting service that seamlessly helps researchers with both computation and data management questions.
